item.title: Freer Monads, More Extensible Effects
item.description: 1. Derivation of Free-er Monad 1.1 Reader Effect Reader computations depend on a value supplied by the environment/context. A side-effect can be understood as an interaction of an expression with its context. The possible requests of a Reader can be specified as a data type. data It i a = Pure a | Get (i -> It i a) The expression Pure e marks the computation e that makes no requests, silently working towards a value of the type a.

item.title: Fusion for Free
item.description: Free monads are at the heart of algebraic effect handlers, a functional approach for modelling side effects which allows the separation of the syntax and semantics of effectful operations, whilst enabling us to provide multiple different semantics for the same syntax. The syntax of primitive side-effect operations is captured in a signature functor. The free monad over this functor assembles the syntax for the individual operations into an abstract syntax tree for an effectful program.
